subsection.title: Real Variables

para.sentence: See Figures 19.3.1–19.3.6 for complete and incomplete Legendre’s elliptic integrals.

subsection.sentence: Figure 19.3.1: K\left(k\right) and E\left(k\right) as functions of k^{2} for -2\leq k^{2}\leq 1 . Graphs of {K^{\prime}}\left(k\right) and {E^{\prime}}\left(k\right) are the mirror images in the vertical line k^{2}=\frac{1}{2} .

Figure 19.3.2: R_{C}\left(x,1\right) and the Cauchy principal value of R_{C}\left(x,-1\right) for 0\leq x\leq 5 . Both functions are asymptotic to \ln\left(4x\right)/\sqrt{4x} as x\to\infty ; see ( ) and ( ). Note that R_{C}\left(x,\pm y\right)=y^{-1/2}R_{C}\left(x/y,\pm 1\right) , y>0 .

Figure 19.3.3: F\left(\phi,k\right) as a function of k^{2} and {\sin^{2}}\phi for -1\leq k^{2}\leq 2 , 0\leq{\sin^{2}}\phi\leq 1 . If {\sin^{2}}\phi=1 (\geq k^{2} ), then the function reduces to K\left(k\right) , becoming infinite when k^{2}=1 . If {\sin^{2}}\phi=1/k^{2} (<1 ), then it has the value K\left(1/k\right)/k : put c=k^{2} in ( ) and use ( ).

Figure 19.3.4: E\left(\phi,k\right) as a function of k^{2} and {\sin^{2}}\phi for -1\leq k^{2}\leq 2 , 0\leq{\sin^{2}}\phi\leq 1 . If {\sin^{2}}\phi=1 (\geq k^{2} ), then the function reduces to E\left(k\right) , with value 1 at k^{2}=1 . If {\sin^{2}}\phi=1/k^{2} (<1 ), then it has the value kE\left(1/k\right)+({k^{\prime}}^{2}/k)K\left(1/k\right) , with limit 1 as k^{2}\to 1+ : put c=k^{2} in ( ) and use ( ).

Figure 19.3.5: \Pi\left(\alpha^{2},k\right) as a function of k^{2} and \alpha^{2} for -2\leq k^{2}<1 , -2\leq\alpha^{2}\leq 2 . Cauchy principal values are shown when \alpha^{2}>1 . The function is unbounded as \alpha^{2}\to 1- , and also (with the same sign as 1-\alpha^{2} ) as k^{2}\to 1- . As \alpha^{2}\to 1+ it has the limit K\left(k\right)-(E\left(k\right)/{k^{\prime}}^{2}) . If \alpha^{2}=0 , then it reduces to K\left(k\right) . If k^{2}=0 , then it has the value \frac{1}{2}\pi/\sqrt{1-\alpha^{2}} when \alpha^{2}<1 , and 0 when \alpha^{2}>1 . See § .

Figure 19.3.6: \Pi\left(\phi,2,k\right) as a function of k^{2} and {\sin^{2}}\phi for -1\leq k^{2}\leq 3 , 0\leq{\sin^{2}}\phi<1 . Cauchy principal values are shown when {\sin^{2}}\phi>\frac{1}{2} . The function tends to +\infty as {\sin^{2}}\phi\to\frac{1}{2} , except in the last case below. If {\sin^{2}}\phi=1 (>k^{2} ), then the function reduces to \Pi\left(2,k\right) with Cauchy principal value K\left(k\right)-\Pi\left(\frac{1}{2}k^{2},k\right) , which tends to -\infty as k^{2}\to 1- . See ( ) and ( ). If {\sin^{2}}\phi=1/k^{2} (<1 ), then by ( ) it reduces to \Pi\left(2/k^{2},1/k\right)/k , k^{2}\neq 2 , with Cauchy principal value (K\left(1/k\right)-\Pi\left(\frac{1}{2},1/k\right))/k , 1<k^{2}<2 , by ( ). Its value tends to -\infty as k^{2}\to 1+ by ( ), and to the negative of the second lemniscate constant (see ( )) as k^{2}(={\csc^{2}}\phi)\to 2- .

subsection.title: Complex Variables

para.sentence: In Figures 19.3.7 and 19.3.8 for complete Legendre’s elliptic integrals with complex arguments, height corresponds to the absolute value of the function and color to the phase.

subsection.sentence: Figure 19.3.7: K\left(k\right) as a function of complex k^{2} for -2\leq\Re(k^{2})\leq 2 , -2\leq\Im(k^{2})\leq 2 . There is a branch cut where 1<k^{2}<\infty .
Figure 19.3.8: E\left(k\right) as a function of complex k^{2} for -2\leq\Re(k^{2})\leq 2 , -2\leq\Im(k^{2})\leq 2 . There is a branch cut where 1<k^{2}<\infty .

Figure 19.3.9: \Re(K\left(k\right)) as a function of complex k^{2} for -2\leq\Re(k^{2})\leq 2 , -2\leq\Im(k^{2})\leq 2 . The real part is symmetric under reflection in the real axis. On the branch cut (k^{2}\geq 1 ) it is infinite at k^{2}=1 , and has the value K(1/k)/k when k^{2}>1 .

Figure 19.3.10: \Im(K\left(k\right)) as a function of complex k^{2} for -2\leq\Re(k^{2})\leq 2 , -2\leq\Im(k^{2})\leq 2 . The imaginary part is 0 for k^{2}<1 , and is antisymmetric under reflection in the real axis. On the upper edge of the branch cut (k^{2}\geq 1 ) it has the value K\left(k^{\prime}\right) if k^{2}>1 , and \frac{1}{4}\pi if k^{2}=1 .

Figure 19.3.11: \Re(E\left(k\right)) as a function of complex k^{2} for -2\leq\Re(k^{2})\leq 2 , -2\leq\Im(k^{2})\leq 2 . The real part is symmetric under reflection in the real axis. On the branch cut (k^{2}>1 ) it has the value kE\left(1/k\right)+({k^{\prime}}^{2}/k)K\left(1/k\right) , with limit 1 as k^{2}\to 1+ .

Figure 19.3.12: \Im(E\left(k\right)) as a function of complex k^{2} for -2\leq\Re(k^{2})\leq 2 , -2\leq\Im(k^{2})\leq 2 . The imaginary part is 0 for k^{2}\leq 1 and is antisymmetric under reflection in the real axis. On the upper edge of the branch cut (k^{2}>1 ) it has the (negative) value K\left(k^{\prime}\right)-E\left(k^{\prime}\right) , with limit 0 as k^{2}\to 1+ .
